title: Tuesday, 24th May, 2016

The US-based rating agency said late on Monday night that it had cut the rating for Deutsche’s unsecured senior debt to Baa2 from Baa1, two notches above junk status. It also cut the lender’s long term deposit rating one notch from A2 to A3.

Moscow, Russian Federation (24 May 2016) - Public Joint Stock Company "MegaFon" (LSE: MFON), a leading Russian telecommunications operator, ("MegaFon" or the "Company") announces that the Company's Board of Directors approved the calling of an Extraordinary General Meeting of Shareholders ("EGM") to terminate powers of the Board of Directors elected at the AGM and elect a new Board of Directors.

http://www.investe...1605240742380990Z/

11:12 am

BE

PM

Probably all too complex for us to cover on the fly -- but you're doing a good job

11:13 am
BE

I used to have to edit Russian stories when at Bloomberg. It was a nightmare.

PM

I bet

BE

The names alone are a bloody minefield. And if you get a vowel in the wrong place all hell breaks loose.

11:14 am
BE

VTB Capital back in April wrote .....

BE

MegaFon’s Board has today accepted CEO Ivan Tavrin’s resignation.
Tavrin is to leave the company on 29 April and move to MegaFon’s
major shareholder, USM Holding. The board has proposed Sergey
Soldatenkov, the current Chairman of the Board, as new CEO.
Soldatenkov knows the company well, and during his previous tenure
as CEO (2003-12) the company gained a lot of market share (+12pp
among the Big 3) and overtook VimpelCom as #2 in Russia. MegaFon
invested a lot into the network over that period, but now the situation is
different as the company does not need to gain scale anymore. The
capex/dividend ratio would rather be defined by shareholder needs.

BE

CEO changeover. MegaFon’s board has today accepted CEO Ivan Tavrin’s
resignation. Tavrin is to leave the company on 29 April and move to
MegaFon’s major shareholder, USM Holding, where he is a shareholder. The
board has proposed Sergey Soldatenkov, the current Chairman of the Board,
as new CEO. Soldatenkov is to be acting CEO ahead of his appointment by
shareholder meeting.
Soldatenkov at the helm again. Soldatenkov knows the company well. He
was at the helm from 2003 to 2012, and since then has been Chairman of the
Board. While Soldatenkov was CEO, the company gained market share
(+12pp among the Big 3) and overtook VimpelCom as the #2 mobile
operator. However, we note a possible caveat associated with Soldatenkov’s
potential appointment: MegaFon has historically invested a lot into the
network (e.g. 2009-12 were years of high investment at a cumulative 30%
capex-to-sales), and Soldatenkov’s arrival might mean another capex spike
(which could serve well in the long term, but would curb cash flows and
dividends in the short term). Having said that, we think the environment has
changed a lot (MegaFon does not need to gain scale anymore, given its 30%
revenue market share), and the capex/dividend ratio could be driven by
shareholders, rather than management. We also note that the arrival of a
new CEO sometimes leads to team reshuffling, which could mean
management continuity issues.

11:21 am
BE

It's been a long road, this.

PM

With regard to OM Asset Management plc ("OMAM"), Old Mutual confirms that it has received approaches from third parties to acquire its stake in OMAM. There can be no certainty that these approaches will lead to any transaction or any certainty as to the terms on which any such transaction might proceed. Further statements will be made if and when appropriate.

PM

Certainly has

11:21 am
BE

Plan to IPO the US asset management side was announced in 2009.

BE

Want some valuation work? Here's JP Morgan to provide that.

BE

It's worth diddly-squat really. Only 18% of the SOTP.

11:23 am
BE

We value this business at $2.1bn, a 6% discount to its IFRS book value and MCEV
carrying value of $2.3bn. Our valuation is at a 25.2 times FY09 PE and at 16.5 times
its FY10E earnings. Given that our valuation is in line with market ratings (see Table
9), we would not foresee an uplift to our SOTP from an IPO. Indeed, given the high
operational gearing and the profit share arrangements with affiliate managers, we
believe a market-average PE rating would be difficult to achieve in an IPO.
OML in our view might do better by listing individual affiliates that currently have
strong league table positions, brands, net inflows and tolerable operational gearing. It
could also use an IPO to further empower affiliate managers and sort out profit share
arrangements whereby profits are shared but no losses are shared. We believe this
would reduce the market risk and better align interests between OML and affiliate
managers. Selective listings of some affiliates would be more likely to enhance the
MCEV, NAV and SOTP valuation for OML, in our view. Given the fickle nature of
asset manager league table positions and brands, we would consider this approach as
more likely to optimise value to OML shareholders.

BE

USAM’s 82% cost-to-income ratio (in FY09) is significantly higher than that of most
listed peers, leading to a high beta (market risk). This needs to be considered in the
valuation for this business and when comparing its P/E to that to of listed peers. The
structure whereby only profits and not losses are shared by affiliate managers also
increases downside market risk.
Even though OML’s US asset management business is more operationally geared
than most of its listed peers in the next table, our carrying value puts it on a par
FY10E PE rating to peers. From the PE comparison, it can be seen that we expect
earnings to recover at a similar rate as is projected by consensus for peers.

PM

Hang on Bryce

http://www.investe...160524080100P5FC7/

PM

Guscio plc, the technology company focused on programmes in physical literacy and sporting assessment, is pleased to announce that trading in its Ordinary Shares of 0.1 pence each (“Ordinary Shares”) has commenced today on the AIM market of the London Stock Exchange. The Company has acquired two revenue generating technology businesses, Sportsdata Limited (“Sportsdata”) and Dataplay Holdings Limited (“Dataplay”) which are focused on tracking and assessing physical literacy and performance in sport. These businesses were acquired for a total consideration of approximately £2.5 million satisfied by the issue of 62,501,308 new Ordinary Shares at a price of 4 pence per share. The Company has also raised £1.5 million before expenses by way of a placing of 37,500,000 new Ordinary Shares at a placing price of 4 pence per share. Allenby Capital Limited is the Company’s Nominated Adviser and Joint Broker and Peterhouse Corporate Finance Limited is its Joint Broker.

PM

Well, it's tiny

11:30 am
PM

Commenting, Guscio’s Managing Director, Gail Ganney, said: “With obesity being a well-documented, rising issue amongst children, we sought to utilise our expertise and specialist skillset to develop a proprietary technology that we believe will provide a better outlook for children across the country, enabling them to live longer, healthier and happier lives. Guscio’s two acquisitions of revenue generating technology companies provide the platform from which to deliver this goal.

“Through the Sportsdata platform we have established a strong relationship with a leading charity, the Youth Sport Trust and together we developed the digital, physical literacy assessment programme for the UK school market, skills2achieve (“S2A”). Launched in February 2015, S2A is being sold into UK primary schools and we are now expanding beyond the primary stage and exploring opportunities in international markets.

“Dataplay is our latest offering, a white-label platform that can be suitably adapted to track, assess and evidence progress and impact in sport, for both participants and organisations. Having built credibility with our partners, we were able to secure our first contract with the YST in December 2015 for the development of the platform for the innovative Youth Sport Award, planned for launch in September 2016. We are now excited to be in advanced talks with several high profile sporting associations to develop and deliver similar solutions.

PM

Richard Charles Thompson (Commercial Director), aged 51, has worked with a number of public and private companies during the last 25 years. His early career began with Hillsdown Holdings plc, and he later became involved in a number of smaller public companies in various sectors. He has also had an active involvement in the sports sector, having been chairman of Queens Park Rangers Football Club and Windsor Race Course as well as having been director of Leeds Sporting plc. In recent years he has focussed on a number of private company investments across sectors that include retail, technology, media and property.

11:36 am
Kingfisher PLC (KGF:LSE): Last: 368.20, up 7.7 (+2.14%), High: 370.30, Low: 365.50, Volume: 4.32m
BE

It was fun when Kingfisher was trying to break China, and failing spectacularly. Now it's just a story about efficient sourcing of mops.

BE

Still, Jefferies is pleased. Incoming.

11:37 am
BE

KGF's Q1 update confirmed strong progress in the UK and Poland, mixed in
France. The completion of B&Q closures and of the B&Q Easier roll-out add to
the good news. Valuation and uncertainty on UK competitive dynamics could
represent ST headwinds, but we remain bullish on LT fundamentals.
Good Q1 with KGF’s sales growth in-line with consensus at +5.1% (+2.3% ex fx) to £2.72bn
(JEFe/cons £2.69bn/£2.72bn). LFL delivery was better than hoped for in all major divisions
(except for Castorama France), and especially at Screwfix and Poland (the two highest
margin and ROCE businesses).

BE

Strong UK performance with LFL of +6.2% reflecting a buoyant trading backdrop and
strong share gains at Screwfix (where LFL of +16.2% takes the 3-year Q1 stack to

40%).

Screwfix's unrivalled multichannel strength remains a powerful driver. B&Q LFL of 3.6%
(vs. JEFe/cons +3%) benefitted from store closures, while strength in indoor sales offset the
14.2% fall in weather-beaten seasonal products. The new IT platform is now fully rolled out
to B&Q, which should provide scope for major improvements in in-store execution. The
65 B&Q store closures have also completed, with the remaining 24 sites outsourced to a
specialist.

BE

France a mixed bag, with Casto LFLs of -0.9% slightly light and Brico's +1.5% somewhat
ahead. Lead indicators remain supportive, but for now a recovery in housing transactions
appears to be mostly lifting spend in furniture rather than larger projects.
Poland soaring (LFL +10.8%) as fiscal stimulus seems to be lifting spend. Understandably
KGF is reluctant to assume this is sustainable as some pulling forward of demand may have
occurred here.

11:38 am
BE

Many attractions to KGF given the LT stimulus from KGF One to an already strongly
freecashflow generative model, as well as the early stage international expansion of Screwfix.
Near-term we are mindful of the stock's major relative rerating YTD, as well as the ambitions
of a deep-pocketed Bunnings in the UK. But the risks from the latter should be weighed
against a Homebase store/customer base which is drastically different from Bunnings'
domestic positioning.

BE

Valuation/Risks
420p PT = 17.4x 2017 PE / 14.3x for 2018 (15.4x/13.6x respectively ex transformation costs),
at the higher end of history given improving French cyclical support, continued shift in the
UK profit base towards Screwfix and longer-term margin benefits from ONE. Risks: reversal
of demand in the UK, France or Poland and major disruption in the implementation of ONE

BE

Sorry about the duff formatting.

11:39 am
BE

And Davy.

BE

Kingfisher has issued a short Q1 trading update. Sales for the
period have grown by 3.6% in like-for-like (LFL) terms to
£2,723m. The LFL performance is therefore ahead of both our
and consensus expectations, driven by strong performances at
Screwfix and in Poland. Across the group, key end markets
remain variable – most notably in France. We have regularly
cautioned that the more difficult operating environment is
likely to make progress relating to ONE Kingfisher more
difficult. That said, the group continued to make decent
progress in that regard. Thus, Kingfisher has made an
encouraging start to what is an important year for the group.

BE

@P asks about Ocado ........

BE

BE

11:41 am
BE

Who was up to 14.6%, last I checked, and has loaned out much of it with the ability to recall on a whim.

BE

It all doesn't look terribly safe to me, particularly for the punter trying to invest on average basket size trends.

PM

sheesh

11:43 am
BE

Anyway, Jefferies has a results preview saying the international deal's partly priced in

BE

Which may be fair, or may not, depending on whether there's an international deal.

BE

That's just how markets work, isn't it? Pricing in probabilities and such.

11:43 am
BE

I'm not an analysts tho. What do I know. Here's Jefferies.

BE

Ocado's interims should confirm a near-term -ve forecast bias, given a
challenged UK gross margin backdrop and investment in innovation. We
continue to await for details of a first overseas deal so to calibrate our fair value
assumptions more accurately.
H1 results on 28 June should confirm negative forecast momentum. We model Q2 sales
growth of 14.6% (retail 13%) to give 15% for H1. We expect EBITDA margin to fall back by
30bps, due to a combination of pricing pressures (we assume underlying gross margin of
-10bps) and investments in innovation. This should be partly offset by further improvements
in both drop densities and pick productivity. The latter has not been helped by a delay in
CFC3 becoming operational (originally scheduled for late 2015), even if we assume mgmt
will confirm Andover is due to come on stream imminently. We forecast H1 closing net debt
of £160m (inc MHE JVco).

BE

Conflicting share price drivers are emerging, and we still await the first international
agreement so to calibrate the option value of overseas prospects more accurately. Ahead of
that, and on the more negative side, we note the push by Amazon (AMZN US, Buy, $703)
into UK food, sustained levels of deflation domestically and the yet unknown impact of the
ongoing review of contract terms with Morrisons. Admittedly the latter does come with the
potential of incremental longer term sales potential. And also on the more positive tack we
note that multi-channel competitors are starting to acknowledge the need to align more
closely delivery charges with the cost of providing an online service to shoppers.

11:44 am
BE

Already pricing in some international value as we currently estimate Ocado.com UK
stand-alone to be worth 180p. Our Ocado International option value of 85p assumes that
Ocado International partner sales build to £700m by 23/24. This option value is extremely
sensitive to fee assumptions (5% vs JEFe at 2% would see that value increase from £530m
to £1.25bn, or to around 200p/share). While the opportunity to blue-sky is limitless on the
international front, the decade-long cashflow history of Ocado UK does not lend itself to a
particularly bullish, DCF-derived domestic fair value. But as can be seen above, a number of
factors are set to change as new developments emerge.

PM

We've been waiting for this imminent international deal for how long?

BE

Couple of years.

11:45 am
BE

I like the theme of Ocado's tech and knowhow actually not being any value at all, because it's all off-the-shelf and logistics isn't really that difficult.

BE

No idea if it's true, but it's entertaining.

BE

James Grzinic is the analyst above, by the way. And apologies for over-quoting him today.

BE

Oh! You're right. It's a day when Anglo isn't up or down 5% on no news.

11:47 am
PM

On commodities I see UBS is going on about upside risk -- on the back of China

PM

And think Daniel Morgan there is back from some trip

PM

Upgrade to China GDP, Fixed Asset Investment & Property Construction
China's key economic statistics released today for Mar-16 were ahead of market
expectations. This has prompted the UBS China economics team, to upgrade GDP
forecasts for 2016 to 6.6% (from 6.2%), including a lift in property sales, construction
& better fixed asset investment (FAI). But as a house we are sceptical that the property
recovery can be sustained at its current momentum for long. See [link to Tao's note].
Commodities implication? Consensus surplus in iron ore & copper a risk
Clearly China's better economic momentum in general & lifting property activity in
particular are positive for commodity demand. Stronger data is challenging our
narrative of 2016 surpluses & projected price weakness in iron ore & copper. In forming
our latest views Breathing Easier published a week ago on 8-Apr-16 we factored in
'green-shoots' apparent in China's property data & FAI. At that time we lifted our
China copper demand to 4% (from 3%) & halved our market surplus to ~125kt in
2016, (Can the Panda Bear eat the Copper surplus?). Our Steel Team is not changing
their China steel production forecast of -4% in 2016 which drives our iron ore iron ore
model into surplus of 34Mt in 2016e. Steel production in China would need to contract
at a more modest ~1% to consume this.

11:48 am
PM

Pendulum shifting towards upside risk case
We are not yet changing our views or price forecasts. But risks are swinging
asymmetrically towards the upside. If property activity continues tracking ahead of our
estimates, then projected surpluses in iron ore & copper could be consumed. Our latest
quarterly piece considered an upside price scenario, see p8.

PM

What do we need to see from here to change our views?
Were the Q1 property statistics & FAI momentum to be sustained through to April &
May we may need to factor in higher demand & prices. We continue to advocate a
market-weight exposure to commodities & exposed equities. After a week of marketing
our views, we believe many institutional investors are underweight the sector. Being
underweight is fighting against an economy where credit is running at Rmb6.5trn for
2016Q1, +41%y/y.

PM

That last line

11:48 am
PM

credit growth at 41%

PM

Sustainable? sure. china take

PM

Credit has been robust so far in 2016
 Total Social Financing (credit growth) for the month of Mar-16 was Rmb2.34trn
YTD, which was well ahead of market expectations of Rmb1.4trn.
 Credit for the Mar-16 quarter was 6.5trn Rmb, +41%y/y, a pace of growth not
seen since 2013.
 Even with unfavoured sector status, credit is leaking into property and
underwriting a pickup in activity
 Our upside scenario in "Breathing Easier" is increasing in likelihood

11:50 am
PM

A chart

BE

Brief stopover at Entertainment One, I guess.

Entertainment One Ltd (ETO:LSE): Last: 180.00, down 0.1 (-0.06%), High: 182.80, Low: 165.80, Volume: 1.36m
BE

Hey! Entertainment One! Your "coming soon" slate still lists Christmas With the Coopers!

11:52 am
BE

BE

http://uk.eonefilm...-a737-69ef6c0aec5a

BE

11:53 am
BE

So .... results. They're okay!

BE

Cashflow's not as bad as usual.

BE

Because they've cut back massively on film "investment" (I'm not sure that's the right word but let's go with it).

11:54 am
BE

.... But also warn that costs will return to normal rates in 2017, so the whole "business that can generate actual cash" thing remains highly theoretical.

BE

Note also the beat's on selling music rights, not TV.

BE

Which isn't seen as a key bit of the business, because .............. well, EMI.

11:55 am
BE

Credit Suisse can take us through the detail.

BE

FY16 EPS -1% lower: Entertainment One released their FY16 results this
morning broadly in line with consensus revenue and EBITDA but -1% lower
at EPS due to a higher interest charge. Overall guidance for the Group was
unchanged reiterating their expectation to double to size of the business by
2020. On the back of these results, we lower FY17 EPS by -1% and leave
FY18 EPS broadly unchanged, leaving us +3% and +2% ahead of
consensus respectively.

BE

TV and Music strong, Family slightly weaker: TV revenues were 3%
ahead of consensus while growth in the non-core music business was 20%
ahead of consensus; however, this was offset by -5% lower Family revenues
and 20% higher elimination from higher DVD sales. We believe the strong
growth in the TV business is encouraging and while we do not see any cause
for concern, investors may be slightly disappointed to see Peppa Pig, the
important driver of growth and cash generation, being supported by the non-
core Music business.

11:55 am
BE

■
Cash generation improved, though expected to weaken again in FY17:
The Group reported +£33m FCF in 2016, a significant improvement
from -£38m in FY15. However this was largely due to significantly lower
investment in content due to the weak box office market and we expect cash
generation to turn negative in FY17 once investment in content returns to
more "normal" levels.
■ Valuation: Entertainment One trades on 7.4x 2017E EV/EBITDA a 36%
discount vs European Media (ex internet) on 11.5x CY2016E EV/EBITDA.
We believe this discount is warranted given the historically low/negative cash
generation, unpredictable and often volatile earnings. At our 160p target
price Entertainment One would trade on 6.6x FY17 EV/EBITDA.

BE

And Canaccord, who remain positive on their client.

BE

eOne’s numbers look broadly in line with market expectations. On a headline basis,
underlying EBITDA of £129m and adj. dil. EPS of 19.4p are a touch ahead of consensus
expectations for £128.4m and 19.2p, respectively.
Film revenues were down 7% on £553m, which indicates a recovery in Q4 from the run-
rate in the first three quarters of the year. Management reiterated that the film slate for
FY17 is stronger than in recent years and this should help to stabilise group performance
– the 210 theatrical releases in FY16 were in line with guidance, and management is
expecting 220 releases in FY17, including The BFG from Amblin Entertainment.
The TV division posted EBITDA of £39.2m which was broadly in line with our
expectations. Management is guiding to 1,100 half-hours of content in FY17 compared
with 998 in FY16. The Mark Gordon Company should also see an increase in production
in FY17, with Designated Survivor and Conviction both in production, to be distributed
internationally by eOne. We remain confident in the potential for this division.
And the Family division has had a good performance thanks to Peppa Pig and PJ Masks
- EBITDA of £43m was in line with expectation. PJ Masks’ merchandising programme
launches in the US in autumn 2016 and the broadcast roll-out to 30 Disney channels
internationally will continue this year, and production has started on a new series of
Peppa Pig.
Recent bid speculation has highlighted eOne’s discount to peers – it trades on just 6.5x
calendar 2017E EV/EBITDA against a peer group on 9.2x. Our initial take is that today’s
results will be broadly reassuring for investors, and the outlook for FY17 is encouraging
with a stronger Film slate and the TV and Family divisions set to deliver further growth.

11:56 am
BE

Remember that time ITV was going to buy E1? That was fun. Rubbish, but fun.
